study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a smartphone-based intervention could improve cardiac rehabilitation program (CRP) completion rates and assess the correlation between daily walking time and six-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The intervention group had a higher CRP completion rate (88% vs. 67%) and showed a significant correlation between daily walking time (measured via smartphone app) and 6MWD at discharge. No significant differences were found in baseline or discharge measurements between groups.
population_specificity: 66 participants commencing a hospital-based cardiac rehabilitation program.
study_duration: Duration of the cardiac rehabilitation program (not explicitly stated in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine if meeting the recommended 150 min/week of moderate-intensity exercise (via 2,000 steps/day) could protect skeletal muscle health during bed rest in older adults.
results_summary: Performing 2,000 steps/day did not prevent loss of lean leg mass or improve aerobic capacity, strength, or muscle fiber volume, but it preserved insulin response to an oral glucose challenge. The intervention was insufficient to fully counter the catabolic effects of bed rest.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (68 ± 2 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the interest and contribution of 3D gait analysis (3DGA) in managing patients with haemophilia, particularly for detecting early walking changes and monitoring arthropathy progression.
results_summary: The study found that 3DGA is useful for detecting early walking changes in paediatric haemophilia patients and monitoring worsening gait in adults with arthropathy, but its routine use is limited by time and cost constraints. The small, heterogeneous patient groups make generalizations difficult, suggesting a need for larger cohort studies.
population_specificity: Patients with haemophilia, including paediatric and adult populations with joint deterioration or arthropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a 12-week walking program (control group) versus a strength and conditioning program (intervention group) on injury rates and strength in chiropractic students learning manual therapy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the walking program's effects, as it focuses on the study protocol rather than outcomes.
population_specificity: Chiropractic students enrolled in 3rd or 4th-year manual therapy units at Murdoch University.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking program duration mentioned but not frequency or intensity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between transcranial magnetic stimulation-induced motor evoked potentials (MEPs) and walking outcomes in chronic stroke survivors, as well as the contribution of the contralesional hemisphere to walking recovery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in gait variables between stroke survivors with and without MEPs in the paretic muscles. The MEP+ group showed higher Fugl Meyer lower extremity scores and ankle dorsiflexor strength, but MEP parameters did not predict gait recovery.
population_specificity: 61 chronic stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of retrofitting suburban streets to promote walking and cycling, focusing on health, social, and environmental outcomes, particularly in low-income neighborhoods and for Māori and Pacific people.
results_summary: The study measured multiple outcomes, including changes in travel behavior, physical activity, air quality, road injuries, and perceptions of safety and social connection, but specific results regarding walking's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Low-income neighborhoods, with a focus on Māori (Indigenous New Zealanders) and Pacific people.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a home-based exercise program, including walking, for improving physical and mental health in older individuals on an isolated, doctor-less island.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in physical performance but observed significant improvements in motor and cognitive Functional Independence Measure scores and several domains of the Short-Form 36-item health survey, including physical functions, general health, vitality, and mental health.
population_specificity: Older individuals (mean age 72.6 years in the intervention group, 74.2 years in the control group) dwelling on an isolated, doctor-less island.
effective_dosage: The exercise program, which included walking, was conducted three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity inspiratory muscle training (HIIMT) improves exercise capacity and respiratory muscle strength in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
results_summary: HIIMT improved exercise capacity and inspiratory muscle strength in HFrEF patients, as evidenced by improved VO₂ outcomes and respiratory muscle strength metrics. The study concluded that HIIMT is a useful strategy for these improvements.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and assess a new anatomically-based masking protocol to measure forefoot plantar pressure during shod conditions, focusing on the metatarsal heads.
results_summary: The new masking protocol showed that a metatarsal pad decreased peak plantar pressures distal to and beneath the metatarsal heads by increasing force and contact area proximal to the metatarsal heads, while the traditional protocol only indicated decreased peak pressure and increased contact area in the broader forefoot area.
population_specificity: 36 community-dwelling older adults (mean age 75.6 years ±5.4) with a history of forefoot pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of ageing on motor learning, retention, and interlimb transfer during walking with and without visual feedback.
results_summary: Older adults showed reduced ability to learn, retain, and transfer a new gait pattern compared to younger adults, but these differences depended on visual feedback, with similar performance when feedback was removed.
population_specificity: 44 subjects (24 young adults, 20 older adults)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of botulinum toxin A injection guided by electrical stimulation (ES) versus ultrasonography (USG) in improving walking-related outcomes for post-stroke patients with plantar flexor spasticity.
results_summary: Both ES and USG-guided injections significantly improved walking speed and ankle range of motion, with no statistically significant differences between the two methods in most measures except for specific ankle joint movements at the 3-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Chronic post-stroke patients with plantar flexor spasticity who were able to walk (n=40).
study_duration: Follow-up at 2 weeks and 3 months post-treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of robot-mediated lower limb rehabilitation (using wearable robots or operational machines) compared to conventional manual therapy for stroke-affected patients, focusing on walking independence and speed.
results_summary: Robot-mediated therapy was more effective than conventional therapy in achieving walking independence (primary outcome), but there was no significant difference in walking speed (secondary outcome). Wearable robots had greater acceptability than conventional therapy, while operational machines did not; operational machines were the most cost-effective.
population_specificity: Stroke-affected patients requiring lower limb rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised and home-based walking interventions could improve metabolic syndrome (MetS) in obese, metabolically unhealthy black women at high vs. low breast cancer risk.
results_summary: Among women with a family history of breast cancer, both exercise arms (supervised and home-based walking) showed significant improvements in MetS z scores compared to controls, primarily driven by changes in blood pressure, triglycerides, and HDL. Similar but statistically nonsignificant trends were observed in women with high projected breast cancer risk.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal, obese, metabolically unhealthy black women aged 45-65.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved aerobic exercise or walking-based exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking in cold conditions increases cardiac workload and induces ischemia in patients with stable coronary artery disease (CAD).
results_summary: Walking in cold conditions increased cardiac workload (measured by RPP) compared to neutral conditions, but no signs of myocardial ischemia or abnormal ECG responses were observed. The study suggests walking is safe for stable CAD patients even in cold environments.
population_specificity: Sixteen men (59.3 ± 7.0 years) with stable CAD.
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity walking (60%-70% of max heart rate) for 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effects of tibial internal rotation (IR) exercise on symptoms and function in patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: The IR group showed significant improvements in all outcome measures (walking tests, squatting kinematics, pain, and difficulty), while the NR group improved only in the 10-m walk test. Correcting rotational malalignment via IR exercise was more effective than neutral rotation for improving KOA symptoms and function.
population_specificity: 60 patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise involved leg press with maximal tibial internal rotation or neutral rotation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness, and acceptability of a pedometer-based walking intervention in inactive adults, comparing postal delivery with nurse consultations.
results_summary: Both intervention groups (postal and nurse support) significantly increased daily step counts and moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) compared to the control group, with effects persisting at 3-year follow-up. The postal intervention was cost-effective and provided long-term quality-of-life benefits.
population_specificity: Inactive adults aged 45-75 years without physical activity contraindications, recruited from general practices in London.
effective_dosage: Participants were advised to gradually add "3000 steps in 30 minutes" most days weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 6-month behavioral intervention delivered via the Internet for increasing physical activity (specifically moderate-to-vigorous physical activity) and improving secondary outcomes like mobility, cognition, and quality of life in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study proposed a randomized controlled trial to assess the intervention's impact on physical activity and secondary outcomes, but results were not yet available as the abstract describes the planned methodology rather than findings.
population_specificity: Adults with multiple sclerosis residing in the United States.
effective_dosage: Not specified (behavioral intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: 6 months of intervention, with a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal frequency and duration of whole body vibration (WBV) for reducing spasticity and improving walking speed in individuals with motor-incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between WBV doses and sham-control in the full group analysis, but participants with more severe spasticity showed greater reduction in stretch reflex excitability with high frequency/long duration WBV. The sham-control condition also had effects, suggesting repeated sitting and standing may influence spasticity.
population_specificity: Individuals with motor-incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI) and spasticity.
effective_dosage: Four WBV doses: high frequency (50 Hz)/short duration (180 s), high frequency/long duration (360 s), low frequency (30 Hz)/short duration, and low frequency/long duration.
study_duration: Single-session intervention with follow-up measurements up to 45 minutes post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of the Assistive Device Selection, Training and Education Program (ADSTEP) on falls and walking and sitting activity in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: ADSTEP resulted in fewer falls, reduced sitting, and may have increased walking in PwMS compared to the control group receiving usual medical care.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) who used a walking aid at baseline and had fallen in the previous year (N=40).
effective_dosage: 6 weekly, 40-minute, 1-on-1 sessions with a physical therapist.
study_duration: 6 weeks (with follow-up assessments at 3 months post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of a task-oriented physical activity checklist in assessing daily step count and its association with walking-related activities in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that specific walking-related tasks (e.g., walking for exercise, walks >10 minutes) were significantly associated with daily step counts in COPD patients. A composite score of these tasks showed strong correlations with both baseline and longitudinal changes in step counts.
population_specificity: COPD patients (two cohorts: n = 109 and n = 175).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of exogenous β-hydroxybutyrate (BHB) supplementation on walking economy and perceived exertion in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study compared the effects of BHB supplementation versus placebo on oxygen consumption and perceived exertion during treadmill walking, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome results.
population_specificity: Ten non-aerobically trained individuals (three males, seven females).
effective_dosage: 1 ounce of exogenous BHB solution (KETO) or placebo (CON) consumed 30 minutes before exercise.
study_duration: Single administration prior to exercise testing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the relevance of a multivariate complexity metric in assessing functional changes in younger older adults through a home-based exercise intervention involving walking.
results_summary: The study found a significant rank correlation between changes measured by complexity metrics and the Community Balance and Mobility Scale (CBMS), suggesting that walking-based interventions can improve functional balance and mobility in younger older adults.
population_specificity: Thirty individuals aged 60–70 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of cardiac shock wave therapy (CSWT) for improving myocardial ischemia in patients with refractory angina pectoris.
results_summary: The study found that CSWT improved myocardial ischemia through coronary neovascularization in a porcine model and in patients with refractory angina pectoris, though specific efficacy and safety results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with refractory angina pectoris (mean age 70.9 ± 12.6 years, 38 male/12 female) without indications for PCI or CABG.
effective_dosage: 200 shots/spot at 0.09 mJ/mm² (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify walking practice (steps, duration, intensity, distance) during physical therapy sessions in sub-acute stroke patients and compare differences based on walking ability.
results_summary: Participants took an average of 560 steps over 13 minutes at 44 steps/min, walking 222m per session. Unassisted walkers engaged in more advanced walking practice (more steps, longer duration, higher intensity) than assisted walkers.
population_specificity: Sub-acute stroke survivors undergoing inpatient rehabilitation in Australia.
study_duration: Observed over three physical therapy sessions (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of aerobic exercise, including walking, during chemotherapy for adult patients.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise, including walking, was found to be safe and improved or maintained fitness during chemotherapy. It also enhanced quality of life, physical functioning, and led to earlier return to work, with some evidence suggesting reduced chemotherapy toxicity and improved completion rates.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cognitive benefits of a golf-training programme in community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The golf training group showed significant improvements in logical memory scores but no significant changes in other cognitive tests, physical performance, or depression scores.
population_specificity: 106 Japanese adults aged 65 and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of a fixed-dose combination of naproxen/esomeprazole (NAP/ESO) in juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) patients aged 12 to 16 years, with an exploratory assessment of efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that NAP/ESO was well tolerated, with most adverse events being mild or moderate. Efficacy outcomes showed improvement in JIA symptoms over time, with increasing percentages of patients achieving ACR Pediatric response criteria and improvements in CHAQ discomfort and functional scores.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 12 to 16 years with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).
effective_dosage: Doses were based on baseline weight (specific amounts not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify lifestyle factors, including walking ability, affecting health-related quality of life (EQ-5D-5 L scores) in older hemodialysis patients in Japan.
results_summary: Reduced walking ability was significantly negatively correlated with EQ-5D-5 L scores, indicating poorer health-related quality of life. The study suggests maintaining walking ability through exercise therapy could improve outcomes for older hemodialysis patients.
population_specificity: Older hemodialysis outpatients (aged 65+ years) in Japan with a mean duration of hemodialysis of 15.1 years.

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of a comprehensive nonsurgical training program versus a self-directed approach in improving walking ability in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The comprehensive program showed superior, large, and sustained improvements in walking ability, with 82% of participants achieving clinically meaningful improvement compared to 63% in the self-directed group. Secondary outcomes also favored the comprehensive program at 6 and 12 months.
population_specificity: 104 participants (mean age 70.6 years, 57% women) with neurogenic claudication and imaging-confirmed LSS, 84% of whom had leg symptoms for >12 months.
effective_dosage: Not specified (6-week structured comprehensive training program or self-directed program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of additional balloon pulmonary angioplasty (BPA) as a sequential hybrid therapy for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension after pulmonary endarterectomy (PEA).
results_summary: The study found that a sequential hybrid strategy (PEA followed by BPA) improved residual symptoms and exercise capacity compared with PEA alone. Mean pulmonary arterial pressure was significantly improved in the hybrid group.
population_specificity: 20 patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension who had residual symptoms after PEA.
study_duration: The period from PEA to additional BPA was 7.3±2.3 months.

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the clinical benefits of combined transcatheter mitral and tricuspid valve repair (TMTVR) versus mitral valve repair alone (TMVR) in high-surgical-risk patients with significant mitral and tricuspid regurgitation.
results_summary: TMTVR was found superior to TMVR in improving cardiac output and functional outcomes early post-intervention, with sustained clinical benefits up to 18 months. Reduction in mitral regurgitation was similar between groups, but TMTVR significantly reduced tricuspid regurgitation.
population_specificity: High-surgical-risk patients (mean age 79.5 ± 8.4 years, EuroSCORE II 8.6 ± 5.9%) with significant mitral and tricuspid regurgitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between gait deviations (measured by GDI) and walking activity before and after single-event multilevel surgery in youth with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found a weak correlation between changes in gait deviations and walking activity, and a moderate correlation between changes in surgery-related gait deviations and walking activity. While surgery improved gait deviations, this improvement had limited correlation with postoperative changes in walking activity.
population_specificity: 74 youth with cerebral palsy (CP)
study_duration: Preoperative assessment 1-16 months before surgery; postoperative assessment 10-26 months after surgery

study_goal: To re-evaluate the weight loss efficacy of LI85008F in healthy overweight adults through a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical study.
results_summary: The LI85008F supplemented group showed significant reductions in body weight (5.36 ± 1.769 vs. 0.87 ± 1.381 kg) and BMI (2.05 ± 0.693 vs. 0.34 ± 0.559 kg/m²) compared to placebo, with P < 0.0001. The supplement was well tolerated and effective for weight management when combined with modest calorie restriction and physical activity.
population_specificity: Healthy overweight adults (BMI 27-29.9 kg/m²)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of locomotor training (LT) in restoring or developing ambulation in children following spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found improvements in ambulation for all 41 participants following LT, with additional benefits in bowel/bladder management, bone density, cardiovascular endurance, and quality of life. The effectiveness varied based on age, completeness, and level of injury.
population_specificity: Children aged 15 months to 18 years with spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, effectiveness, and feasibility of fitness training, particularly assisted walking, for nonambulatory stroke survivors.
results_summary: Assisted walking significantly improved fat mass, peak heart rate, oxygen uptake, walking endurance, speed, mobility, and balance, while cycle ergometry improved cardiovascular and metabolic markers. Case fatality and adverse events were low, suggesting safety and efficacy.
population_specificity: Nonambulatory stroke survivors (FAC score ≤2), primarily in acute settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adjunctive inspiratory muscle training (IMT) enhances the benefits of pulmonary rehabilitation in patients with COPD.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in the primary outcome (6MWD) but observed additional gains in endurance cycling time and reductions in dyspnoea symptoms in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Patients with COPD (FEV1 <50% predicted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of robot-assisted gait training with ankle dorsiflexion assistance on gait independency and motor recovery in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that active ankle assistance improved gait independency, motor recovery, walking speed, and weight acceptance confidence, while the sham group showed reduced leg range of motion.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients with motor impairment at the ankle.
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of 30-minute over-ground walking and stair ambulation practices over five weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine social network predictors of physical activity (PA) change, particularly walking, in Latinas.
results_summary: The study found that network characteristics such as size, familial ties, contact frequency, and support for PA (e.g., co-participating in exercise) were associated with increased moderate-to-vigorous PA (MVPA), including walking. Ego-alter similarities in walking behavior were also linked to greater MVPA.
population_specificity: 102 adult Latinas participating in a randomized controlled PA intervention trial for underactive women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare COPD patients who desaturated within the first minute of the 6-minute walk test with those who desaturated later, identifying potential markers for early desaturation.
results_summary: Early desaturators had higher mean BMI and lower FEV, suggesting overweight and obesity may serve as markers for early desaturation in COPD patients.
population_specificity: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the survival benefits and outcomes of neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by delayed surgery versus immediate surgery with adjuvant chemotherapy in patients with nonmetastatic high-grade pelvic osteosarcoma.
results_summary: The study found no survival advantage or difference in local recurrence-free survival between the neoadjuvant chemotherapy group and the immediate surgery group. The 90% necrosis threshold did not significantly distinguish responders from nonresponders.
population_specificity: Patients with nonmetastatic high-grade primary pelvic osteosarcoma (n=89).
study_duration: Mean follow-up of 61 months (neoadjuvant group) and 77 months (immediate surgery group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether stem cell therapy could improve walking ability in patients with chronic lymphedema compared to compression therapy alone.
results_summary: Stem cell therapy significantly reduced limb circumference, improved pain relief, and enhanced walking ability after 6 months, while the control group showed no significant improvements. Immunohistochemistry confirmed increased lymphatic capillaries in the stem cell group.
population_specificity: 40 patients (18-38 years) with chronic lymphedema, divided into stem cell therapy (n=20) and control (compression therapy, n=20) groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified (bone marrow-derived mononuclear cells transplanted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether functional electrical stimulation for walking improvement in patients with upper motor neurone foot-drop also affects bladder symptoms, particularly in those with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that functional electrical stimulation significantly improved overactive bladder symptoms, specifically urgency and urge incontinence, in multiple sclerosis patients but not in the broader cohort. Greater improvements were observed in patients with lower baseline walking speeds.
population_specificity: 47 patients with upper motor neurone foot-drop, including 35 with multiple sclerosis and 12 with other neurological conditions (e.g., stroke, cerebral palsy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of neuro-orthopedic surgery for spastic equinovarus foot after stroke, focusing on improving walking capacities and achieving personal goals across the ICF domains.
results_summary: The study found that neuro-orthopedic surgery improved walking capacities, reduced spasticity and pain, increased ankle range of motion and gait speed, and enhanced activity/participation domains of the ICF. Patient-centered goals were achieved, and walking aids were reduced.
population_specificity: Eighteen hemiplegic patients with spastic equinovarus foot after stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review cortical activity during walking and balance tasks in older adults and people with Parkinson's disease (PD) using fNIRS and EEG, examining disease-specific mechanisms underlying deficits.
results_summary: The review found increased cortical activity is required for older adults and those with PD to perform walking and balance tasks, with activation patterns varying by task demands. Studies suggested this reflects compensatory mechanisms for age- or PD-related deficits in automatic movement control, but lack of standardization limited clinical relevance.
population_specificity: Older adults and people with Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of three surgical techniques (hybrid external fixation, plate and screws, and intramedullary nailing) for treating tibia fractures and their impact on foot loading and walking recovery.
results_summary: The study found that incorrect reduction of tibia fractures can alter foot loading and pace training, emphasizing the importance of surgeon experience and method knowledge. Outcomes varied by technique, with follow-up assessments at 12 months showing differences in pain, recovery time, and walking recovery.
population_specificity: 34 patients (25 males, 9 females) aged 16-67 years with type A tibia fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) and pharmacological treatment on physical activity (PA), particularly walking, in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with 19 out of 32 PR studies showing a positive effect on PA, while 13 showed no effect. Pharmacological interventions had positive effects in 8 out of 11 studies, with 3 showing no effect. The study suggests that behavioral changes may be necessary for lasting PA improvements.
population_specificity: Stable elderly COPD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether functional treatment with a removable brace is a safe and more comfortable alternative to cast immobilization for stable type B ankle fractures.
results_summary: Functional bracing showed significant improvements in comfort and range of motion at 6 weeks compared to casting, but no significant differences were found after a year. Both treatments were equally safe with no complications reported.
population_specificity: 44 patients with stable type B ankle fractures visiting the emergency department.
study_duration: 6 weeks (primary outcome), with follow-up at 52 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively evaluate gait and balance dysfunction in cerebellar ataxias using motion analysis systems to identify differences from healthy subjects and inform rehabilitation strategies.
results_summary: The study found that cerebellar patients exhibit increased step width, reduced ankle joint range of motion, increased muscle coactivation, and abnormal joint coordination, leading to poor gait stability and upper-body oscillations. Motion analysis provided detailed insights into both primary gait disorders and compensatory mechanisms.
population_specificity: Patients with cerebellar ataxia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether group contingency procedures could reduce problem behavior and improve appropriate line walking in detained adolescents within a residential facility.
results_summary: Fixed-time attention delivery decreased problem behavior during free periods, while rules plus contingencies improved appropriate line walking during transitions, with rules alone maintaining behavior in some cases. Direct training was needed for other transitions.
population_specificity: Detained adolescents in a residential facility (groups of 5 to 11 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of a three-month self-management intervention, including physical activity (walking) and dietary advice, on glycemic control and biochemical outcomes in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that walking and improved dietary habits (higher vegetable, fruit, and bread intake; lower full-fat cheese and spread consumption) in the experimental group led to significant positive changes in physical activity, dietary habits, and some biochemical indicators (higher albumin, lower urea, ALP-Phosphatase, and glucose levels), though no substantial change was seen in HbA1C.
population_specificity: Non-complicated type 2 diabetic patients in Iraq (16 in the experimental group, 23 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the efficacy and safety of bronchoscopic lung volume reduction (BLVR) with endobronchial valve (EBV) implantation for advanced emphysema, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the 6-minute walking test between the EBV group and the control group (WMD=14.12; 95% CI, -4.71 to 32.95; P=0.14).
population_specificity: Patients with advanced emphysema.

study_goal: To assess the effects of automated peripheral stimulation (AMPS) on gait variability in Parkinson's disease patients with freezing of gait (FOG) during single and dual-task walking conditions.
results_summary: AMPS reduced gait variability in Parkinson's disease patients with FOG during both single-task (walking) and dual-task (walking while performing a cognitive test) conditions. The effects were observed while patients were off anti-Parkinsonian medications.
population_specificity: Thirty subjects with Parkinson's disease and freezing of gait (FOG), randomized into AMPS (n=15) and AMPS sham (n=15) groups.
effective_dosage: 2 treatment sessions per week for 4 weeks (total 8 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a patient-centered activity regimen (PCAR) involving walking improved participation and physical activity more effectively than weekly phone calls in patients with advanced-stage lung cancer.
results_summary: PCAR resulted in higher device usage (100% vs. 79%), fewer missing data (11% vs. 38%), and increased physical activity in "less active" patients, while "more active" patients saw a decline. Most subjects found PCAR helpful (92%) and were willing to participate in future studies (85%).
population_specificity: Patients with advanced-stage lung cancer
effective_dosage: Walking-based activity regimen with FitBit Flex, an educational session, and twice-daily gain-framed text messages (PCAR group) or weekly phone calls (control group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of physical therapy following botulinum neurotoxin A (BoNT-A) administration on gait electromyography and walking ability in patients with hemiparesis secondary to stroke.
results_summary: BoNT-A monotherapy reduced soleus activity during the stance phase but did not improve walking ability, while BoNT-A plus physical therapy increased muscle activity and knee joint stability during the stance phase and suppressed abnormal muscle activity during the swing phase, leading to improved gait parameters.
population_specificity: Thirty-five patients with chronic stroke and spasticity.
effective_dosage: 300 single doses of BoNT-A administered intramuscularly to the ankle plantar flexors.
study_duration: 2 weeks of physical therapy starting the day after BoNT-A administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of eHealth interventions in promoting physical activity (PA), particularly walking, among community-dwelling older people and to assess the methods used for objective PA measurement.
results_summary: The review found short-term increases in PA (e.g., daily step counts and minutes spent on PA) following eHealth interventions, but evidence for long-term effects was lacking. Studies were often underpowered, highlighting the need for larger, longer-term research.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older people.
study_duration: Varied across studies (not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the most useful clinical scales for evaluating functional impairment, particularly walking and balance, in CMT1A patients.
results_summary: The study found strong correlations between walking and balance evaluations, indicating that better balance control is associated with higher walking speed and fewer perceived physical limitations. The 6MWT, 10MWT, and SPPB were identified as the most useful scales for assessing functional impairment in CMT1A patients.
population_specificity: Fifty-three subjects with a clinical and genetically confirmed diagnosis of CMT1A.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of delivering and evaluating a lifestyle programme, including walking, for patients with colorectal cancer undergoing curative treatments.
results_summary: The study found that walking and other physical activity measures were part of the intervention, but the walk test was not achieved by all participants, and evaluation measures were inconsistently collected across phases.
population_specificity: Adults with stage I-III colorectal cancer in NHS Tayside.
study_duration: Three phases (presurgery, surgical recovery, post-treatment recovery) with a median intervention delivery time of 5.5 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a 10-week exercise program, including walking, during neoadjuvant chemoradiation treatment in rectal cancer patients to counteract treatment-related adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that the exercise program improved leg strength (27.2% in leg press, 22.7% in leg extension) and endurance (76.7%), along with enhanced performance in fast walking speed (6.9%) and dynamic balance (15.5%), despite muscle and fat mass loss. Minimal changes in quality of life and fatigue were observed, with no adverse events related to training.
population_specificity: Rectal cancer patients (7 men, 3 women, aged 27-70 years) undergoing neoadjuvant chemoradiation treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program details not fully described).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and differentiate physical activity programming and counseling preferences, particularly walking, among adult cancer survivors.
results_summary: Walking was the strongest physical activity modality preference among cancer survivors, who also preferred moderate intensity and home-based programs in the morning. Most survivors felt able and interested in participating in such programs.
population_specificity: Adult cancer survivors, primarily mixed groups or breast cancer survivors.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the effect of weight reduction and increasing physical activity (including walking) on foot structure and function in obese Japanese individuals and to compare which intervention was more beneficial.
results_summary: The study found that weight reduction and increased physical activity improved foot structure and function in obese individuals, though the abstract does not specify which intervention was more effective.
population_specificity: Obese Japanese individuals (BMI 29.0 ± 2.5 kg/m²)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare medio-lateral stability between walking turns and straight walking and investigate the effect of walking speed on stability during turning in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Medio-lateral stability was enhanced during turning compared to straight walking, but turning at a slow pace reduced stability due to narrower step width. Pelvis lateral displacement was unaffected by turning speed.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (n=19)

study_goal: To identify and evaluate balance measures used in the spinal cord injury (SCI) population for clinical utility, psychometric properties, and comprehensiveness.
results_summary: The study identified 31 balance measures, with the Berg Balance Scale and Functional Reach Test being valid and reliable, and the mini-BESTest being the most comprehensive. No single measure had high clinical utility, strong psychometric properties, and comprehensiveness.
population_specificity: Adults with spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the test-retest reliability and agreement between two gait modeling methods (a modified Conventional Gait Model and a cluster-based model) using different computational approaches in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found good to excellent test-retest reliability for both gait models in assessing lower limb kinematics and kinetics, with slightly lower reliability for inverse kinematic models compared to six degrees-of-freedom models. Agreement between the Conventional Gait Model and cluster model was mostly good to excellent, with higher agreement observed between modified CGMs than between cluster-based models.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if stenting post-thrombotic iliofemoral obstruction reduces venous hypertension and whether improved haemodynamics enhances quality of life.
results_summary: Stenting significantly reduced venous hypertension in the common femoral vein during walking and correlated with improved quality of life, though no effect was observed in dorsal foot veins.
population_specificity: 12 participants with unilateral post-thrombotic obstruction of the iliac and/or common femoral veins.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of population-level interventions to promote walking among individuals and populations.
results_summary: The review found that mass media, community initiatives, and environmental changes increased walking (range from 9 to 75 min/week). Most studies were from urban high-income countries and used various approaches like tax incentives, policy changes, and scaled-up school-based programs.
population_specificity: Free-living populations, mostly from urban high-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine a benchmark cadence (steps/min) associated with moderate-intensity walking to inform public health recommendations for adults.
results_summary: The study found a strong relationship between cadence and walking intensity, with ≥100 steps/min consistently associated with moderate intensity (3 METs). Peak cadence indicators were negatively associated with age and BMI, and epidemiological studies reported low mean daily cadences in the population.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy of spatiotemporal gait metrics measured by a smart device versus validated inertial sensors during prolonged walking.
results_summary: The study found strong associations (r>0.9) and good agreement between smart devices and inertial sensors for all measured gait parameters (stride duration, cadence, stride length, and gait speed). Smart devices accurately reflected individual leg output, suggesting potential for clinical application in assessing gait in real-world environments.
population_specificity: Twenty neurologically healthy young adults (7 women; age: 25.0 ± 3.7 years; BMI: 23.4 ± 2.9 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of walking interventions on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors and explore dose-response relationships between walking frequency, intensity, duration, and CVD risk improvements.
results_summary: Walking interventions showed favorable effects on seven CVD risk factors, including body mass, blood pressure, and fasting glucose, but the study found insufficient evidence to quantify the specific walking parameters required for optimal benefits.
population_specificity: Inactive but healthy adults aged 18 years or older (81% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and validate indicators of outcome quality for invasive treatments in peripheral arterial disease (PAD), including walking distance as a relevant measure.
results_summary: The study identified walking distance as a highly relevant indicator of outcome quality in PAD treatment, alongside other clinical measures like major adverse limb events and re-interventions. The Delphi consensus approach validated its importance for harmonizing future studies and quality benchmarking.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), including vascular specialists, physician assistants, wound nurses, and patient representatives.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence and factors associated with outdoor footwear types worn most often in a representative inpatient population.
results_summary: The study found that running shoes, thongs/flip flops, walking shoes, sandals, and boots were the most common outdoor footwear types. Sex was the most consistent factor associated with footwear choice, with females more likely to wear thongs and sandals, and males more likely to wear boots and running shoes.
population_specificity: A cohort of 733 inpatients (62 ± 19 years, 55.8% male, 23.5% diabetes) highly representative of developed nations' hospitalized populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if gait training with visual biofeedback and body weight support (BWS) on a treadmill improved outcomes more than BWS treadmill training alone in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: Both groups showed statistically significant improvements in gait parameters, walking speed, endurance, and mobility, but no significant difference was found between the group with visual biofeedback and the control group. The symmetry index change was similar in both groups.
population_specificity: 30 patients with subacute stroke
study_duration: Not specified (implied over the course of 15 sessions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the dose, intensity, and context of physiotherapy for balance and mobility problems after stroke, focusing on walking and related activities.
results_summary: The study found that stroke physiotherapy for balance and mobility problems involved low-dose, low-intensity therapist-led practice, primarily of walking and sit-to-stand, with limited repetitions and time spent upright. Staff-to-patient ratios were high, but key activities like falls prevention were not practiced.
population_specificity: Previously mobile stroke survivors receiving treatment for balance and mobility problems in four inpatient stroke units in North-West England.
effective_dosage: Mean repetitions of sit-to-stand per session: 5 (SD 6.4); mean time spent upright per session: 11.24 minutes (SD 7); mean steps per session: 202 (SD 118).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute exercise response to supplemental oxygen during a 6-minute walking test was associated with long-term survival in patients with obstructive lung disease.
results_summary: The study found that 44.3% of patients walked ≥26 m further with supplemental oxygen, but this acute exercise response did not correlate with long-term survival. The conclusion supports using ambulatory oxygen for symptomatic relief only.
population_specificity: Chronic obstructive lung disease patients who desaturated during exertion (median age 70 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a shoe-mounted inertial-sensor-based gait therapy system providing real-time feedback to normalize gait parameters in individuals with gait impairments due to incomplete spinal cord injury, stroke, or old age.
results_summary: The study found that real-time verbalized feedback significantly improved gait normalization across all groups, with the most notable improvement between the first and second training visits. Users rated the system's usability and therapeutic effect positively.
population_specificity: Individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI), stroke, and elderly participants.
effective_dosage: 5 feedback training sessions of 2-3 minutes per visit.
study_duration: 3 consecutive visits, with a follow-up 4 weeks post-training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of minimally invasive plate osteosynthesis (MIPO) versus open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) for treating Vancouver type B1 periprosthetic femoral fractures (PFFs).
results_summary: MIPO showed comparable fracture healing rates (95.2%) to ORIF (87.5%) with fewer intraoperative complications, shorter operation times, and less blood loss, but no significant differences in walking abilities or other clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with Vancouver type B1 periprosthetic femoral fractures following total hip arthroplasty.
study_duration: Mean follow-up was 33.8 months for MIPO group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the performance of three IMU-based algorithms for step demarcation in lower limb prosthesis users and healthy controls during walking.
results_summary: The zero-crossing algorithm outperformed peak detection algorithms in most participants, showing lower variability in acceleration, more consistent step demarcation, and more normally distributed step durations. The study concluded that the zero-crossing method is more reliable for step demarcation in lower limb prosthesis users.
population_specificity: 17 transtibial prosthesis users, 16 transfemoral prosthesis users, and 14 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a personalized exercise program on falls prevention and gait parameters in lower limb amputees.
results_summary: The exercise group experienced significantly fewer falls over one year and showed improved gait speed compared to baseline. The intervention demonstrated clinically meaningful benefits for falls prevention and walking performance.
population_specificity: Lower limb amputees (transfemoral and transtibial) recruited from prosthetic services centers.
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week program focusing on strength, balance, flexibility, and walking endurance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Accurate-Pain-Reporting-Training (APRT) could improve pain reporting accuracy and reduce placebo response in a trial of Pregabalin for painful diabetic neuropathy, with walking pain intensity as a secondary outcome.
results_summary: APRT significantly improved pain reporting accuracy (p = 0.036) and reduced placebo response (p = 0.018), but no relationship was found between pain reporting accuracy and changes in pain intensity during treatment. Walking pain intensity was measured but not specifically highlighted in the results.
population_specificity: 51 participants with painful diabetic neuropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of telerehabilitation on mobility in people following hip surgery, comparing it to a control intervention.
results_summary: The telerehabilitation group showed greater improvements in five of six mobility tests compared to the control group, with notable gains in the 2-min walking test (86.1%) and walking speed (65.6%). Improvements persisted at follow-up for the telerehabilitation group, while the control group showed no changes in most measures.
population_specificity: 40 participants (22 male, 18 female) with a mean age of 67.5 years following hip surgery.
effective_dosage: 3 sessions/week for 6 weeks (telerehabilitation via video clips; control group received an exercise booklet). Both groups also had twice-weekly physical therapy sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre- and perioperative gabapentin administration influences chronic postoperative pain and psychological state 3-4 years after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study found no significant association between gabapentin treatment and reduced chronic postoperative pain or improved psychological state (PCS, HADS-A, HADS-D) 3-4 years after TKA, despite lower postoperative pain scores compared to preoperative levels.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
study_duration: 2 hours before and 6 days after operation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare three sit-to-stand test protocols (5-rep STS, 30-s STS, and 1-min STS) and their correlations with clinical outcomes, functional exercise capacity, and physical activity in daily life in COPD subjects.
results_summary: The 1-min STS showed significant correlations with functional exercise capacity (6MWT) and physical activity in daily life, while all three protocols were able to identify subjects with low or preserved exercise capacity. The 1-min STS generated higher hemodynamic demands but had good agreement with the other protocols.
population_specificity: 23 subjects with COPD (11 men)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Tai Chi training versus conventional exercise on dual-tasking performance in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in dual-tasking performance between Tai Chi and conventional exercise groups post-intervention or at follow-up. Within-group improvements were observed in the Tai Chi group for dual-tasking performance, but these were not superior to conventional exercise.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of home-based rehabilitation, including walking, in improving mobility and daily activity for patients recovering from hip fracture.
results_summary: Home-based rehabilitation significantly improved mobility, daily activity, instrumental activity, and balance but had no significant effect on walking outdoors, usual gait speed, fast gait speed, or emergency department visits.
population_specificity: Patients with hip fracture (887 participants across 9 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify short-term predictors of lower extremity amputation (LEA) in patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFU), including the role of walking disability.
results_summary: The study found that the presence of any walking disability was an independent predictor of short-term LEA in DFU patients, along with moderate to severe infection, previous LEA history, and peripheral arterial disease. Walking disability increased the risk of LEA within 180 days (OR 3.35).
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFU) observed in a multidisciplinary outpatient diabetic foot clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify which gait training method (heel-focused, forefoot-focused, or general gait intervention) better improves walking and balancing abilities in adult patients with chronic hemiplegic stroke.
results_summary: All groups showed significant improvements in walking and balancing, but the heel and forefoot groups (using auditory feedback) demonstrated larger gains compared to the control group, particularly in center of loading path length and velocity, as well as functional gait assessment.
population_specificity: Adult patients with chronic hemiplegic stroke recruited from a rehabilitation hospital.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of comprehensive rehabilitation therapy plus an additional 20 minutes of gait intervention (with or without auditory feedback), three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to report a case of aggressive angiomyxoma (AA) and its impact on the patient's mobility, particularly walking, due to tumor growth in the abdomen and perineum.
results_summary: The study found that the tumor's growth impeded the patient's daily life and walking, leading to incomplete resections and long-term misdiagnosis. The case highlights the challenges in diagnosing and treating AA, with residual tumor remaining post-surgery.
population_specificity: A 36-year-old woman with aggressive angiomyxoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of dark tea wine (DTW) on metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and obesity in a rat model.
results_summary: DTW enhanced antioxidant capacity by activating the Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathway, leading to reduced weight gain, improved lipid metabolism, and amelioration of MASLD pathology in rats fed a high-fat diet.
population_specificity: Rats with MASLD induced by a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the effects of PVPP on the quality characteristics of Viognier wine when added pre- or post-fermentation compared to an untreated control wine.
results_summary: PVPP-treated wines had significantly lower concentrations of monomeric phenolics and browning pigments than the control wine. PVPP addition pre-fermentation reduced oxidation, and aroma profiles differed significantly from the control, with no difference between pre- and post-fermentation treatments.
population_specificity: Viognier wine
effective_dosage: Commercially recommended levels (specific amount not stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of non-Saccharomyces yeast species on the aromatic profile of red wines made from the Babić grape variety.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in volatile aromatic compounds, contributing to floral, fruity, and buttery aromas, with Td x Sc treatments showing particularly positive sensory properties. Sensory evaluation confirmed enhanced fullness, harmony, aftertaste, and overall impression in these wines.
population_specificity: Red wines made from the cv. Babić grape variety from Middle and South Dalmatia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of organic mulching practices on wine physicochemical properties, phenolic composition, and sensory qualities compared to conventional soil management methods.
results_summary: Wines from organic mulching treatments showed higher pH, potassium, and hue, and lower tartaric acid, with SMC mulch resulting in reduced anthocyanins, flavonols, and hydroxycinnamics. No sensory differences were detected between mulching and conventional treatments.
population_specificity: Wine produced from vineyards using different soil management practices (organic mulches vs. conventional tillage/herbicide) in two locations over four years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether lactic acid bacteria isolated from palm wine and fermented cow milk could alleviate neuropathic pain in mice induced by chronic constriction injury.
results_summary: The study found that pretreatment with Limosilactobacillus fermentum and Enterococcus lactis significantly reduced neuropathic pain symptoms (mechanical hyperalgesia and cold allodynia), comparable to morphine, by enhancing antioxidant activity, reducing inflammation, and lowering calcium deposition in the sciatic nerve.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice with induced neuropathic pain.
effective_dosage: Different concentrations (specific amounts not stated), administered orally via gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of red wine on inflammatory markers related to atherosclerosis in healthy individuals and high-risk subjects for cardiovascular disease compared with moderate alcohol consumption.
results_summary: Red wine significantly decreased several inflammatory markers in healthy subjects but not in CVD patients, with some variations based on country and intervention duration. It was more effective than white wine in reducing atherosclerosis-related inflammation in healthy individuals.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and high-risk subjects for cardiovascular disease.
study_duration: Varied (subgroup analysis noted effects in interventions lasting less than 3 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers were not studying Wine; the abstract focuses on metronomic chemotherapy for cancer treatment.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the mechanisms and benefits of metronomic chemotherapy, including its antiangiogenic properties, immunomodulatory effects, and potential combinations with other therapies, but does not mention Wine.
population_specificity: High-risk cancer patients and those with metastatic disease.
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (related to chemotherapy, not Wine).
study_duration: Not mentioned (related to chemotherapy, not Wine).
interactions: None mentioned (related to chemotherapy, not Wine).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to diagnose and manage a case of atypical Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) in an adult patient with an extrafacial port-wine birthmark and delayed-onset seizures.
results_summary: The study found that SWS can present atypically in adults with extrafacial port-wine stains and delayed seizures, and clinical diagnosis may be necessary in resource-limited settings. The patient was treated with Levetiracetam for seizure prevention.
population_specificity: A 55-year-old man with an extrafacial port-wine birthmark and new-onset seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review non-invasive methods for evaluating treatment efficacy in port wine stains (PWS) and summarize their advantages and disadvantages.
results_summary: The study found that current PWS treatments rely on subjective clinician judgment, and non-invasive visualization instruments (e.g., dermoscopy, OCT, HFUS) can improve efficacy assessment, though deeper structures may require combined technologies. Future integration of these methods could overcome limitations of single technologies.
population_specificity: Individuals with congenital vascular malformations (port wine stains) on the face and neck.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether red wine has aromatase-inhibiting properties that could play a role in chemoprevention of estrogen-dependent breast cancer.
results_summary: The study suggests that red wine, but not white wine, may contain constituents like polyphenols, tannins, and resveratrol that could inhibit aromatase, potentially reducing local estrogen production linked to tumor proliferation. However, the exact mechanisms remain unclear, and while animal studies support this effect, clinical evidence is insufficient to advocate for red wine as an aromatase inhibitor.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (with implications for premenopausal women, though the role is unclear).

study_goal: The researchers were not studying wine; they were evaluating the clinical efficacy and safety of HMME-PDT for treating port-wine stains (PWS).
results_summary: The study found that HMME-PDT was effective in treating PWS, with 27.27% of patients cured and 30.30% showing improvement. Most patients reported local pain and edema, but no systemic adverse effects were observed.
population_specificity: Thirty-three patients with port-wine stains (PWS).
effective_dosage: Intravenous HMME with irradiation using 532 nm green LED light; treatment sessions varied (1 to more than 3 sessions).
study_duration: Treatment duration varied by patient (from January 2019 to March 2020).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-aging mechanism of Polygonatum sibiricum (PS) and its wine-steamed processed product (WPS) in mice, focusing on the Keap1/Nrf2/ARE pathway and intestinal flora.
results_summary: WPS outperformed raw PS in improving body weight, mental state, and oxidative stress markers in aging mice, likely due to activation of the Keap1/Nrf2/ARE pathway and regulation of intestinal flora.
population_specificity: Kunming mice (aging model induced by D-galactose).
effective_dosage: 5, 10, or 15 g/kg/day of RPS or WPS administered intragastrically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foliar melatonin application could mitigate salt stress effects on grapevine physiology and fruit quality in 'Pinot Noir' wine grapes.
results_summary: Melatonin improved photosynthetic capacity, leaf health, and fruit quality (e.g., weight, size, acid content) under salt stress, with 100μmolL-1 being the most effective concentration. It reduced oxidative stress markers and enhanced stress tolerance.
population_specificity: Wine grape (Vitis vinifera) 'Pinot Noir' plants under simulated salt stress (200mmolL-1 NaCl).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to compare the clinical outcomes of a variable-sequenced, long-pulsed 532-nm KTP laser and PDL in treating port-wine birthmarks (PWB).
results_summary: The study found that the KTP laser had comparable efficacy to PDL in treating PWB, with fewer post-treatment reactions and no system failures. Patients were satisfied with both treatments, and 96% would recommend both modalities.
population_specificity: 35 patients (mean age 42.1 years, 63% female) with port-wine birthmarks.
effective_dosage: 1 to 5 treatment sessions at intervals of 6-8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the efficacy and adverse effects of hemoporfin-PDT in treating port-wine stains associated with phakomatosis pigmentovascularis, not Wine.
results_summary: The study found that hemoporfin-PDT was effective for treating port-wine stains in PPV patients, with better outcomes in areas without overlapping pigmentary nevus. Minor side effects like edema and hyperpigmentation were observed.
population_specificity: Patients with phakomatosis pigmentovascularis (PPV) and associated port-wine stains (PWS), aged 2-31 years.
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (study analyzed two sessions of hemoporfin-PDT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the viability of a porous zirconia-impregnated material (ZrO2/Al2O3) for effectively removing turbidity-causing proteins in white wine.
results_summary: The study found that high-temperature treatment (750 °C) of ZrO2/Al2O3 significantly improved wine stability and protein adsorption, reducing turbidity (ΔNTU from 42 to 18) and total protein content by 44%, particularly targeting proteins in the 10-70 kDa range. The modified material's enhanced pore diameter and surface properties contributed to these results.
population_specificity: White wine (no human or animal subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects and mechanisms of wine-processed Gentiana radix (WGR) on damp-heat jaundice syndrome (DHJS) in rats.
results_summary: WGR improved liver function indicators and metabolic pathways better than non-wine-processed Gentiana radix (GR), restoring biomarkers related to arachidonic acid metabolism, steroid hormone biosynthesis, and other pathways. WGR was particularly effective in improving porphyrin and chlorophyll metabolism.
population_specificity: Rats with induced hepatic injury (DHJS model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of aspergillopepsin I (AP-I) and flash pasteurization on the chemical composition and protein stability of Sauvignon Blanc and Gewürztraminer grape musts and wines.
results_summary: AP-I supplementation reduced unstable proteins (chitinases and thaumatin-like proteins) and increased amino acids in heated musts. Flash pasteurization and AP-I treatment altered aroma compounds but did not significantly affect wine tasting descriptors, except for a slight decrease in floral intensity and typicality in heated wines.
population_specificity: Sauvignon Blanc and Gewürztraminer grape musts and wines.
effective_dosage: AP-I supplementation with must heating at 70°C (HP treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of MPCTS@PDA@pancreatin as a biocatalyst for detoxifying Ochratoxin A (OTA) in wine.
results_summary: MPCTS@PDA@pancreatin demonstrated >58% OTA detoxification in wine, retained 43% activity after 8 reuse cycles, and showed no significant impact on wine quality or cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nanodrug-loaded microneedle system combining rapamycin and photochlor for anti-angiogenesis and photodynamic therapy to treat port-wine stains.
results_summary: The study found that the RPM-HPPH NP@HA MN effectively delivered the nanodrug percutaneously, demonstrated strong cytotoxic effects on EOMA cells under laser irradiation, and penetrated the stratum corneum in mouse skin. The combination therapy showed statistically significant enhanced efficacy compared to free RPM.
population_specificity: Mouse hemangioendothelioma endothelial cells (EOMA) and nude mice skin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if reusing distillation residuals from Chinese wolfberry wine could reduce environmental pollution while maintaining or improving the physicochemical properties, antioxidant activity, and flavor compounds of the recombined brandy.
results_summary: The study found that ceramic membrane filtration combined with D401 resin effectively removed Cu (II) from the residuals. The recombined brandy had higher polysaccharides, phenols, and flavonoids, enhancing antioxidant capacity, and GC-IMS identified 25 volatile compounds with significant differences between recombined and finished brandy.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on the product, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of once-weekly pulsed dye laser (PDL) treatments for port-wine birthmark (PWB) in infants.
results_summary: The study found that 70% of infants achieved near-total or total clearance of PWB after 2 months of once-weekly PDL treatments, with the remaining 30% showing marked improvement. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Infants younger than 6 months with port-wine birthmarks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether ultrasonic treatment during fermentation could enhance the quality of fortified wines by improving chemical composition and sensory attributes.
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment increased total anthocyanin and phenol content, reduced anthocyanin degradation, improved color stability, and lowered ethyl carbamate levels after aging. Optimal settings (200 W for 20 min) improved sensory scores, while higher settings (400 W for 40 min) enhanced volatile compounds and aroma.
population_specificity: Fortified wines (no specific human population studied).
effective_dosage: Ultrasonic treatment at 200 W for 20 min or 400 W for 40 min.
study_duration: Duration of ultrasonic treatment during fermentation (exact fermentation duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of laser versus LED light sources for Hemoporfin photodynamic therapy in treating port-wine stain birthmarks.
results_summary: Both laser and LED light sources induced significant vascular injury and color bleaching in chicken wattles, with laser showing greater vascular clearance but LED demonstrating more uniform distribution and better safety. The study suggests LED may be favorable for larger port-wine stain lesions.
population_specificity: Chicken wattles (animal model for port-wine stain birthmarks)
effective_dosage: Same doses of 532 nm light for both KTP laser and LED

study_goal: The abstract does not mention any study related to Wine.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss any findings related to Wine.
population_specificity: Not applicable

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the potential of MSC-derived extracellular vesicles (MSC-EVs) in delaying skin aging, not Wine.
results_summary: The abstract discusses MSC-EVs' anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidative stress, and wound-healing properties, but does not mention Wine.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on MSC-EVs, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of various additives, particularly glutathione-enriched inactive dry yeast (g-IDY), in preventing browning caused by ascorbic acid degradation in cili wine.
results_summary: g-IDY showed the strongest inhibitory effect on browning, increased antioxidant capacity, and preserved ascorbic acid and phenolic content better than SO2-treated wine. The treatment also reduced oxidation-prone o-diphenols, maintaining wine quality over 12 months.
population_specificity: Cili wine (Roxburgh rose wine) with high ascorbic acid content.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ultrasonic treatment of Saccharomyces cerevisiae could improve fermentation efficiency and volatile flavor quality in rice wine.
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment significantly increased biomass and alcohol yield, reduced fermentation time by nearly 2 days, and enhanced the quantity of flavor compounds, particularly esters and alcohols, in rice wine.
population_specificity: Saccharomyces cerevisiae seed culture in rice wine fermentation.
effective_dosage: Fixed-frequency ultrasonic treatment (28 kHz, 45 W L-1, 20 min).
study_duration: Not specified (intervention applied at logarithmic metaphase of seed culture).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a quantitative method to evaluate the efficiency of vascular-targeted photodynamic therapy (V-PDT) for treating port-wine stains (PWS).
results_summary: The study found that V-PDT with good treatment efficiency resulted in larger Euclidean distances and smaller correlation coefficients between pre- and post-treatment images, indicating measurable changes in lesion appearance. The proposed method effectively quantified these differences, suggesting its utility for assessing V-PDT efficiency.
population_specificity: Patients with port-wine stains (PWS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a long-pulse KTP laser in treating PDL-resistant port-wine stains (PWSs).
results_summary: The study found that the long-pulse KTP laser was more effective than PDL for treating PDL-resistant PWSs, required fewer sessions, and had no significant side effects like purpura.
population_specificity: A female patient with PDL-resistant port-wine stains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of HMME-PDT and PDL for treating port wine birthmarks (PWB), particularly in young children.
results_summary: PDL showed slightly higher clearance rates than HMME-PDT, though not statistically significant, with near significance in young children. HMME-PDT lacks long-term safety data, especially regarding CNS development in young children.
population_specificity: Patients with port wine birthmarks, including minors (<18 years) and young children (<3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a green bioprocess for producing bacterial cellulose (BC) using wine distillery effluents (WDE) and biodiesel-derived glycerol, and to evaluate BC's potential as a bio-adsorbent for wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study achieved a maximum BC concentration of 9.0 g/L with high productivity and water-holding capacity. BC demonstrated significant adsorption capabilities, removing up to 50.7% of phenolics, 54.3% of dye acid yellow 17, and up to 97% of metals like Cd from synthetic wastewater.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using bacterial strain Komagataeibacter rhaeticus and synthetic wastewater).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to reduce methanol levels in persimmon wine by optimizing cultivar selection, pretreatment methods, and fermentation conditions.
results_summary: The study found that using the 'MaoKui' cultivar, specific pectinase treatment, and optimized fermentation conditions reduced methanol levels to 77.7 mg/L while achieving a high sensory evaluation score (90.6) and identifying 49 volatile aromas.
population_specificity: Persimmon wine production (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Pectinase (0.03 g/kg), starter (250 mg/kg, BO213 and SPARK mix).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of resveratrol, a compound found in red wine, on adipocytes and adipose tissue in obesity models.
results_summary: The study found that resveratrol may inhibit adipogenesis, promote apoptosis of mature adipocytes, reduce lipid accumulation, and increase thermogenesis, suggesting potential anti-obesity effects. Further research is needed to confirm these findings in clinical settings.
population_specificity: Animal models of obesity and adipocytes in culture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the geographical differences in monoterpene composition in 'Muscat Hamburg' grapes and wines across six Chinese viticultural regions.
results_summary: The study found significant variations in monoterpene content across regions, with the YT region showing the highest levels. Monoterpenes correlated positively with humidity and rainfall, and negatively with sunshine duration and temperature.
population_specificity: 'Muscat Hamburg' grapes and wines from six Chinese vineyards (YT, XF, SS, XX, WW, CL).

study_goal: The study does not address Wine; it focuses on Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS), its clinical features, and dental considerations.
results_summary: The study does not examine Wine; it discusses the etiology, pathophysiology, and treatment of SWS, including oral manifestations.
population_specificity: Patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of triptan intake on dietary habits, particularly the consumption of red wine, in adults with migraine.
results_summary: Triptan users reported red wine as a frequent migraine trigger and consumed it less often than non-triptan users, suggesting increased sensitivity to red wine-induced migraine with regular triptan use.
population_specificity: 314 adults with migraine with and/or without aura, recruited via social media, patient associations, and clinical centers in Denmark.
study_duration: Survey conducted between November 2022 and June 2023 (no specific intervention duration).
interactions: Triptans were associated with increased sensitivity to red wine as a migraine trigger.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing evidence on the effects of red wine and its components on neurocognitive disorders in preclinical and clinical settings.
results_summary: The study found that wine polyphenols in red wine showed protective effects on dementia in preclinical models, but clinical evidence remains uncertain due to the risk-to-benefit ratio of alcohol consumption on brain health. The study concluded that there is insufficient evidence to support red wine consumption for preventing neurocognitive disorders.
population_specificity: Preclinical models and clinical settings (general population, particularly aging individuals at risk of neurocognitive disorders).

study_goal: The study does not address Wine; it focuses on Sturge-Weber syndrome, its characteristics, and treatment options.
results_summary: The study does not examine Wine; it discusses Sturge-Weber syndrome, including its causes, symptoms, diagnostic imaging, and treatment approaches such as laser therapy, anti-seizure medications, low-dose aspirin, and sirolimus.
population_specificity: Patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome, particularly those with facial port-wine stains, brain involvement, and associated neurological symptoms.
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (study does not pertain to Wine).
study_duration: Not mentioned (study does not pertain to Wine).
interactions: None mentioned (study does not pertain to Wine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the color change and fluorescence of resin composites after consumption of beverages, including red wine.
